(5)  Approval of sale. All sales of properties shall be approved by the board of commissioners at a regular scheduled public meeting in which public comment is allowed regarding such sale. 
( Ord. No. 2018-06 , § I, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 2-159. - Disposition of personal property. 
(a)  Declaration of unserviceable or surplus property. The board of commissioners shall determine whether personal property with an original unit purchase cost of $10,000.00 or more can no longer be used advantageously by the county and has therefore become unserviceable or surplus. The purchasing director is delegated the authority to determine whether personal property with an original unit purchase cost of less than $10,000.00 can no longer be used advantageously by the county and has therefore become unserviceable or surplus. 
(b)  Disposition. 
(1)  The disposition of unserviceable or surplus personal property with an original unit purchase cost of $10,000.00 or more must be approved by the board of commissioners and may be sold by public sale, sealed bidding, spot bidding or any other means deemed most advantageous to the county under the particular circumstances as determined by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  The disposition of unserviceable or surplus personal property with an original unit purchase cost of $10,000.00 or less shall be approved by the purchasing director and may be sold by public sale, sealed bidding, spot bidding or any other means deemed most advantageous to the county under the particular circumstances as determined by the purchasing director. 
(3)  A sale to a private person shall be for the highest net purchase price reasonably obtainable by the county. A sale to another unit of government shall be for a fair and reasonable purchase price that need not be as high as the purchase price obtainable from a private person. 
(4)  If the residual value of an item of personal property is determined by the purchasing director after reasonable inquiry to be $100.00 or less, the property may be disposed of by the purchasing director in such manner and for such consideration, which need not be monetary, as the county manager deems most advantageous to the county under the circumstances. 
(5)  If the residual value of an item of personal property is determined by the purchasing director after reasonable inquiry to be $100.00 or less, the property may be provided to a retiring employee by the county manager in recognition of their retirement and years of service to Troup County, Georgia. 
( Ord. No. 2018-06 , § I, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 2-160. - Leases of county-owned real property. 
(a)  The board of commissioners may offer to lease county-owned real property if: 
(1)  The sale of the real property is not in the best interest of the county but the real property is not currently being used to be best advantage of the county. 
(2)  The real property has been newly acquired but not immediately put to use by the county, and may reasonably be leased on a month-to-month or short-term basis. 
(b)  A lessee's interest under any lease executed under this section shall constitute a usufruct only. 
(c)  Where county-owned real estate is to be leased for nonpublic use, public notice of the availability of the real property shall be published once in legal organ and on the county website, soliciting inquiries and offers. The notice shall include as part of the solicitation the requirement that improvements to the real estate be insured for the county's benefit at the lessee's expense. The solicitation shall also describe any restrictions to be placed on the use of the real property. The county manager shall report to the board of commissioners all offers to lease the real estate and shall make recommendations as to which offer is in the county's best interest. The board of commissioners shall approve the offer that it deems to be in the best interest of the county. Such approval shall constitute authority for the chairman to execute a lease and any instruments on behalf of the county necessary to accept and effectuate the offer. 
( Ord. No. 2018-06 , § I, 9-18-2017) 
Secs. 2-161—2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COURTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-201—2-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDIGENT DEFENSE SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2005-03, § 1, adopted February 1, 2005, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as Art. V, Div. 2, §§ 2-226—2-230 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-226. - Application for indigent defense services. 
Each person lacking the financial ability to pay for legal representation in his or her defense in criminal proceedings in and before the State Court of Troup County, Georgia, and desiring that the county provide such services to him or her, shall submit an application to the county requesting indigent defense representation and setting forth the specifics supporting their need for such indigent representation. 
The application shall be completed and submitted to the court administrator upon intake at the jail or at the court administrator's office or at any state court appearance on a form approved by the governing authority of the county. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 1, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-227. - Application fee. 
Each applicant for indigent defense services shall pay an application fee of $50.00 (or the maximum fee allowed by O.C.G.A. § 15-21A-6, as the same may be amended) to the court administrator of the county. Such fee must be paid either at the time the application is submitted or at the time the representation is provided. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 2, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-228. - Waiver. 
The fee required by section 2-227 may be waived only upon order of the presiding judge scheduled to hear the case in which applicant is seeking a waiver of the application fee. The judge may order a waiver of the fee only upon a finding by the court that the defendant is unable to pay the fee or that paying the fee would cause hardship to the defendant. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 3, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-229. - Transfer of funds. 
Within 15 days after the end of each month, the court administrator shall remit the total of all application fees collected pursuant to this division to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 4, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-230. - Separate account. 
The board of commissioners shall maintain all funds remitted to it pursuant to this division in a separate "Indigent Defense Services Account" and funds from such account shall be expended only for the purpose of providing legal representation to indigent defendants in and before the State Court of Troup County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 5, 2-1-2005) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section I(Exh. A) of Ord. No. 2014-02 , adopted Nov. 5, 2013, repealed ch. 6, §§ 6-1—6-4, 6-26—6-32, 6-52—6-58, 6-90, 6-109—6-114, 6-142—6-144, 6-172, 6-198—6-214, 6-237, 6-300—6-302, 6-323—6-331, 6-353—6-365, 6-391—6-396, and enacted a new ch. 6 as herein set out. Former ch. 6 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2010-06, § I(Exh. A), adopted Dec. 1, 2009. 
Cross reference— Smoking in county buildings and motor vehicles, § 2-3; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 38; standards for building construction, § 38-121 et seq.; historical preservation, ch. 42; manufactured homes, ch. 46; planning, ch. 58; roads and streets, ch. 66; solid waste disposal, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. C. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Necessity of regulations. 
In accordance with the laws of the state, it is necessary and expedient for the county to exercise its police powers to establish and promulgate certain standards and regulations in regard to the sale, tax and control of packaged malt beverages and/or wine, as well as the sale for consumption on the premises of malt beverages and/or wine, in the unincorporated areas of the county. The business of manufacturing, distributing, selling, handling, and otherwise dealing in or possessing malt beverages and/or wine, as well as the business of selling malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises, is declared to be a privilege, not a right, and such privilege shall not be exercised in the county except as licensed under the terms of this chapter. This chapter does not permit the sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises. Such sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises is expressly prohibited. Except as otherwise specifically provided for herein, this chapter does not permit the sale of any alcoholic beverages for consumption off the premises of the licensee. Licensing shall be solely for the unincorporated areas of the county. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever means processed. 
Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, liquors, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine, or fortified wine. 
Authorized catered function means a function in the unincorporated portions of the county for which an event permit has been issued by the county. 
Bed and breakfast home means a residential structure occupied as principal residence by the owner(s) of record wherein lodging or lodging and breakfast only is provided to guests for compensation. 
Bed and breakfast inn means a building or dwelling unit, not necessarily owner-occupied, that offers transient lodging accommodations and breakfast for four or more guest rooms for compensation provided. 
Charitable organization means a nonprofit organization created for charitable purposes, which has received and maintained approval from the United States Internal Revenue Service as a bona fide section 501(c)(3) organization. 
Church means a building where persons regularly assemble for religious worship intended primarily for purposes connected with such worship. 
Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. 
Farm winery means a winery which makes at least 40 percent of its annual production from agricultural produce grown in the state and: 
(1)  Is located on premises, a where minimum of 20 percent is used for agricultural purposes, including the cultivation of grapes, berries, or fruits to be utilized in the manufacture or production of wine by the winery; or 
(2)  Is owned and operated by persons who are engaged in the production of 20 percent of the agricultural produce used in its annual production. 
Food caterer means any person who prepares food for consumption off the premises, possesses a valid occupational tax certificate, and meets all Troup County Environmental Health regulations. 
Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "fortified wine" includes, but is not limited to, the term "brandy." 
Gallon and wine gallon means a United States gallon of liquid measure equivalent to the volume of 231 cubic inches or the nearest equivalent metric measurement. 
Golf course means a tract of land publicly or privately owned that is a minimum of two acres designed and laid out for playing the game of golf, and improved with tees, greens, fairways, hazards, practicing and playing and driving range and may include a club house with dressing rooms, dining facilities, professional shop and meeting space. 
Host means the person who organizes the catered event and who will be responsible, along with the licensed alcohol beverage caterer, for compliance with the rules set forth in this chapter. In the event that the host is an organization rather than an individual, the organization will designate one individual who will be the host for the purposes of this chapter. 
Importer means any person who imports an alcoholic beverage into this state from a foreign country and sells the alcoholic beverage to another importer, broker, or wholesaler and who maintains a stock of the alcoholic beverage. 
License means the authorization by the board of commissioners to engage in the retail sale of malt beverages and/or wine, either in unbroken packages not for consumption on the licensed premises (also referred to hereinafter as a "package license") or for consumption only on the licensed premises (also referred to hereinafter as a "pouring license"). 
Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer means any retail dealer who has been licensed by the state to sell alcoholic beverages pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 3, ch. 4, art. 2, O.C.G.A. ch. 5, art. 2 , or O.C.G.A. ch. 6, art. 2. 
Licensed location means the place where a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer maintains its principal place of business within the county. 
Licensee means any person who has been issued a license by the board of commissioners to engage in the retail sale of malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages not for consumption on the licensed premises (also referred to hereinafter as a "package licensee") or for consumption only on the licensed premises and not for resale (also referred to hereinafter as a "pouring licensee"). 
Lounge means a separate room where malt beverages and/or wine are served by the drink which is either connected with or part of a restaurant (as defined herein) and operated in conjunction therewith and under the same management as the restaurant operations. Lounges shall not be permitted. 
Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. 
Manufacturer means any maker, producer, or bottler of an alcoholic beverage. Manufacturer also means; in the case of malt beverage, any brewer; in the case of wine, any wine maker. 
Meal means the delivery and service of food in individual portions or by means of a self-service buffet to individual patrons of a place of business. The service of food to a patron shall not constitute a meal if payment for same is combined with payment of a cover charge or entrance fee or if payment for same is in fact merely ancillary to the service of malt beverages and wine. All meals must be prepared in the place of business for which the license is issued. 
Minor means any person under the age of 21 years, or as defined in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 or by other state laws. 
Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel or other original consumer container. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other entity, group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. 
Place of business means the premises described in the license issued pursuant to this chapter. For the purposes of this chapter, a "place of business" shall consist of one physical building and shall not include any adjacent structures that are not physically attached to the premises by heated and cooled space. Two or more separate, detached structures may not be combined to meet the requirements of this chapter. Outdoor patios or decks which are completely enclosed by a fence or wall and are accessible only through an enclosed building shall be considered as a part of a place of business. 
Premises means the location where the licensee is authorized to sell malt beverages and/or wine. 
Private club means a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state, actively in operation within the county at least one year immediately prior to the application for a license hereunder, having at least 100 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly or semiannual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofit purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any shareholder or member, and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining and using a sufficient number of employees for cooking, preparing and serving meals at least five days a week for its members and guests. Such club shall also be an organization which has received and has maintained approval from the United States Internal Revenue Service as a bona fide section 501(c)(3) organization. The building of such club shall be air-conditioned. To qualify as a private club under this chapter, no member or officer, agent or employee of the club may be paid, or directly or indirectly receive, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages by the club to its members or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. No license shall be issued to any location or maintained at any location that does not have adequate on-premises parking as required by the then applicable parking regulations of the board of commissioners. 
Restaurant means any public or private place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the general public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations. Such place shall be air-conditioned and contain adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and seating capacity for at least 50 people, and have employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its patrons. At least two distinct and separate meals per day shall be served at least five days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating or renovation. The serving of such meals and food shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of malt beverages and/or wine to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. 
Retailer or retail dealer means, except as to distilled spirits, any person who sells alcoholic beverages, either in unbroken packages or for consumption on the premises, at retail only to consumers and not for resale. With respect to distilled spirits, the term means any person who sells distilled spirits in unbroken packages at retail only to consumers and not for resale. 
School means a building, publicly or privately owned, which is used for teaching or giving instruction in any subject to pupils of the school. The term "school" shall not mean a private residential dwelling in which a child receives home schooling from a parent or other person. 
Tasting room means an outlet for the promotion of a farm winery's wine manufacturer by providing samples of such wine or malt beverage to the public and for the sale of such wine or malt beverage at retail for consumption on the premises and for sale in closed packages for consumption off the premises. Samples of wine or malt beverage can be given complimentary or for a fee. 
Wholesaler means any person who sells malt beverages and/or wine to other wholesale or retail dealers, or licensees. 
Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. 
Sec. 6-3. - Incorporation of federal and state law and regulations. 
The federal and state statutory laws and/or regulations relating to the sale and/or distribution of alcoholic beverages within the state and the United States of America are hereby incorporated herein and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-4. - Sale on election days. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, the sale of alcoholic beverages on local election days is hereby authorized and permitted so long as such sales are in compliance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-5—6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE, LICENSEE AND PREMISES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-26. - State law compliance. 
All pertinent state laws and regulations shall be complied with by any licensee under this article as a condition of having that license. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-27. - Hours and days of sale. 
Except as may be otherwise provided herein, any person licensed under this article may sell malt beverages and wine on days as prescribed by applicable state law governing hours and days of sale. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-28. - Health and fire standards. 
Licensees under this article shall meet and continue to meet all health and fire regulations applicable to their business and location. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-29. - Purchase invoices. 
Each licensee under this article shall maintain copies of all purchase invoices for malt beverages and wines at his place of business and have same available for examination by county officials at any time during normal working hours. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-30. - Public drinking or consumption of alcohol. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages while on or in a public area or way or upon any county-owned property unless such consumption is during a permitted special event pursuant to article VI of chapter 66 of this Code and pursuant to an event permit as provided in article V of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be or appear to be in an intoxicated condition upon any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own, other than by invitation by the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by boisterous or indecent behavior or acts, or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Cross reference— Roads and streets, ch. 66. 
Sec. 6-31. - Possession of open container while operating a motor vehicle. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Open container means any container which is immediately capable of being consumed from or the seal of which has been broken. 
(b)  Possession. No person shall possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle or as a passenger in a motor vehicle. For the purposes of this section, an open container shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator or occupant of a vehicle if the container is not located in a locked nonpassenger area of the vehicle. A container shall not be considered open if it remains sealed in its original container and condition. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 74. 
Sec. 6-32. - Inspection. 
It shall be the duty of the sheriff or other constituted authorities to inspect all establishments licensed pursuant to this article periodically to determine that no violations hereof exist. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-33—6-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSEE QUALIFICATIONS 

Sec. 6-52. - Age requirement. 
No package license or pouring license shall be granted to any person or partnership unless the person or all partners or members shall be at least 25 years of age, shall be of sufficient mental competence to execute a contract under the laws of the state, and has/have been a resident of the state for a minimum of one year prior to filing an application for such license. In the event a corporation should be an applicant and said corporation has not been incorporated and/or allowed to do business by the secretary of state for said one-year period, then the incorporator of said corporation and the owners of at least 80 percent of the stock of said corporation shall all have been residents of the state for one year prior to filing an application for such license. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-53. - Sworn statement. 
The applicant shall make a sworn statement of the applicant's qualifications according to the provisions of this chapter and shall place the same on file with the building official before any license is issued. ( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-54. - Ineligibility—County officials; county employees; county board members. 
No officials or employees of the county, or member of the board of commissioners shall be eligible to receive a package license or pouring license. However, any private club is not automatically disqualified from receiving a retail consumption pouring license because such club is organized or owned by or operated by one or more members of the board of commissioners and/or employees thereof. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-55. - Same—Prior criminal record. 
No applicant who has a conviction of or has pled nolo contendre within the previous ten years of the date of application to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the county. No license shall be granted to an applicant who has been convicted under any federal, state or local law for a criminal offense involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or tax law violations if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the county. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-56. - Same—Previous denial. 
Any applicant denied a license shall be prohibited from applying for another license for a period of one year from the filing date set forth on the application. Any partnership, company, corporation, trust or other entity in which an individual applicant is a member, shareholder, director or officer, or in which such entity acts as a surrogate for such applicant, shall also be subject to the prohibition contained in this section. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-57. - Corporate and partnership applicants. 
(a)  If the applicant is a partnership or limited liability company, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. 
(b)  If the applicant is a corporation, the manager of the proposed licensed premises must be qualified to obtain a license and must make a sworn statement of these qualifications. A corporate license applicant shall appoint and designate to the board of commissioners an agent authorized to receive service of process under the laws of the state. If no such designation is made, the board may serve or notify the applicant or license holder at any address of the applicant or license holder known to the board. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-58. - Adequate participation. 
A license may be denied to any applicant where it appears that the applicant would not have adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended to be a mere surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license for any reason whatsoever. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-59—6-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE APPLICATION 

Sec. 6-90. - Guidelines. 
Application for a license shall be made on forms furnished by the board of commissioners according to the following guidelines: 
(1)  All license applications shall be presented in person to the building official. 
(2)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2, as a prerequisite to the issuance of an initial license only, the applicant shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints to be forwarded to the state bureau of investigation, which shall search the files of the state crime information center for any instance of criminal activity during the two years immediately preceding the date of the application. The state bureau of investigation shall also submit the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the rules established by the United States Department of Justice for processing and identification of records. The federal record, if any, shall be obtained and returned to the board. 
(3)  All licenses shall be valid only for the calendar year indicated thereon and renewed no later than December 31 of that year. 
(4)  All licensees shall be required to obtain and maintain and produce upon request by the building official, his/her designee, or any law enforcement officer a current State of Georgia license as well as meet all requirements for a Troup County license. 
(5)  Please see chapter 10 articles III, IV and V for additional regulations regarding alcoholic beverages as they pertain to entertainment centers, amusement centers and billiard rooms. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-91—6-108. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PREMISES 

Sec. 6-109. - Separate license. 
(a)  A separate license shall be required for each place of business, as defined herein. 
(b)  In addition, each pouring license granted will enable the licensee to sell the malt beverages and wine for consumption only in the areas of the premises allowed by state statutory laws and regulations. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-110. - Building compliance. 
(a)  The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all ordinances of the board of commissioners, rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner, and the statutory laws of the state. Upon completion, the proposed building shall be subject to final inspections and approvals by the building inspector and fire marshall. 
(b)  Each applicant for a license shall attach to his or her application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building, or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. 
(c)  Licensees shall provide on the premises for which the license is issued adequate sanitary toilet facilities as required by the health and building codes, and the building shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passageways and open areas may be clearly seen by customers therein. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-111. - Distance requirements. 
(a)  No license shall be granted to any person unless the entire business premises of the proposed location is situated beyond 100 yards from the property line of any church and not less than 200 yards from any schoolyard or college campus, and not less than 100 yards from any building used as an alcohol rehabilitation center. The distance shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. 
(b)  Any business approved prior to these distance requirements being adopted may continue to renew their business license provided the business is not vacant more than six months provided the business does not fail to operate upon the premises pursuant to a valid alcohol license for more than six months. Businesses that are vacant for more than six months without a valid alcohol license shall reapply and shall meet all distance requirements as set out in subsection (a). 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-112. - Inspections. 
The business premises of the licensee shall be made available for inspection at any and all times by officers or officials authorized to conduct such inspections. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-113. - Days of operation. 
No licensee shall furnish, sell or offer for sale any malt beverages and/or wine: 
(1)  At any time other than as allowed in sections 6-325 and 6-365 of this chapter; or 
(2)  At any time in violation of a state statutory law, state rules or regulations, local ordinance or regulations. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013; Ord. No. 2014-06 , § I, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 6-114. - Gambling. 
There shall be no gambling, betting, games of chance, punch boards, vending machines, slot machines, pinball machines, lotteries, or tickets of chance therein or the operation of any schemes for hazarding money or any other thing of value in any licensee's place of business or any room adjoining the same, owned, leased, or controlled by the licensee; provided, however, that the sale of state lottery tickets in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq., shall be permitted. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-115—6-141. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DENIAL OF LICENSE 

Sec. 6-142. - Grounds. 
(a)  The board of commissioners, in its discretion, may consider any and all relevant and extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application or the proposed location of the business. If, in the judgment of the board of commissioners, circumstances are such that the granting, suspension or revocation of the license would or would not be in the best interest of the general public, then such circumstances may be grounds for the denial of the application. 
(b)  Any misstatement, false statement, or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for the denial of the application for license issuance or revocation of the license issued and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury under the laws of the state. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-143. - Notice of denial. 
The board of commissioners shall give notice in writing to the applicant of any decision to grant or deny an application. The notice shall provide a summary of the reason(s) for the decision. Notice shall be given by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-144. - Denial hearing. 
(a)  Whenever the board of commissioners shall deny an application for a package license or pouring license, the applicant shall have ten days following the date of receipt of such notice of the denial to request a hearing before the board. If a hearing is requested, the following information shall be given to the applicant, in writing, by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested, at least ten days prior to the hearing date: 
(1)  The date, time and location of the hearing, said hearing date not to be more than 20 days from the date of said written notice; 
(2)  A written statement of the reason for the proposed denial of the application; 
(3)  A list of witnesses, if any, the board of commissioners expects to testify or offer evidence in favor of the denial of the application; and 
(4)  Notice of the applicant's right to attend the hearing, to present evidence and testimony, to assert any defense of the application, to confront and cross examine anyone who would testify in favor of denial of application and to have an attorney present to represent the applicant. 
(b)  Any decision denying an application shall set forth the reason for such action in writing, which shall be delivered by regular mail to the applicant's address set forth in the application. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-145—6-171. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - TRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE 

Sec. 6-172. - Transferability. 
(a)  No package or pouring license shall be transferable or assignable to any person or other location, and in the event that a licensed business is sold or closed, it shall be the duty of the licensee to immediately surrender said license to the board of commissioners. Under no circumstances will the license fee be refunded to the holder. 
(b)  All holders of licenses issued under this section shall, within six months after the issuance of such license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment within such period shall serve as a forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license and no refund of the license fee shall be made to the license holder. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-173—6-197. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DUTIES OF LICENSEE 

Sec. 6-198. - Management and operation. 
The licensee shall be responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted and shall be responsible for all violations of this chapter by the licensee's agents and employees. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-199. - Purchase of malt beverages and wine. 
No licensee shall buy or arrange to buy or in any way cause the transfer of any malt beverages and/or wine except from a licensed wholesaler. A licensee under this chapter shall take delivery only at the licensed place of business from a licensed wholesaler by the State of Georgia and/or Troup County. or licensed common carrier acting for a licensed wholesaler. A licensee shall comply with all other requirements, including, without limitation, those set forth at Chapters 560-2 (Ga. Comp Rules and Regs. 560-2-1 et seq., Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division) and 560-8 (Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. 560-8-1 et seq., Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division—Malt Beverages, Wine, Tobacco) of the Georgia Administrative Code, as well as the rules and regulations of the state department of revenue. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-200. - Inventory of malt beverage and wine. 
A licensee shall keep no inventory or stock of malt beverages and/or wine at any place except the licensed place of business, and within the licensed place of business the storage area for malt beverages and/or wine shall be immediately adjacent to and attached to the retail area or area of consumption. No licensee shall enter into any type of arrangement whereby malt beverages and/or wine ordered by the licensee are stored by a licensed wholesaler. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-201. - Display of license. 
A license issued under this chapter shall be displayed prominently at all times on the premises for which it was issued. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-202. - Condition of premises. 
(a)  All premises used for the sale and/or consumption of malt beverages and/or wine, and/or for the storage of malt beverages and/or wine, shall be kept in a sanitary condition, shall be kept in full compliance with the regulations of the county health department, and shall comply in all respects with the county building codes and all applicable fire, health and other safety standards. 
(b)  All licensed premises shall be subject to inspection by the health department, all county fire departments, the building inspector, and all authorized law or code enforcement officers to determine if the premises are in compliance with all county, state and federal rules, regulations, laws and codes. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-203. - Telephone. 
A licensee shall maintain on the premises at all times a telephone in good working order. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-204. - Violent or disorderly history. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person with a criminal record for violence or disorder to frequent the licensed premises or loiter on the premises. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-205. - Prostitution. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person to frequent the licensed premises for the purpose of soliciting prostitution. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-206. - Police reports. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to report to the sheriff's office at the earliest possible time any known incident of a criminal nature that occur on the licensed premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to willfully withhold from the sheriff any information pertaining to any crime that may have occurred on the licensed premises. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-207. - Criminal acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any criminal act to be committed on the licensed premises. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-208. - Compliance with laws. 
In addition to the rules and regulations set out in this chapter, each licensee under this chapter shall comply with all statutory laws of the state, all federal statutory laws, and all rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner relating to the sale and distribution of malt beverages and/or wine in the state; and any violation of same shall subject said licensee to suspension or revocation of his or her license and also may subject said licensee to criminal prosecution by the proper authority as provided by law and the ordinances of the county. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-209. - Production of records. 
In conjunction with any license application or any license issued under the terms hereof, or in conjunction with the revocation, suspension or cancellation of any license or in conjunction with any of the hearings contemplated by this chapter, or in conjunction with the payment or nonpayment of any excise tax levied or to be collected hereunder, the board of commissioners shall have the right to subpoena all or any part of the records, books, documents, reports or invoices of any applicant or licensee. Said subpoena right shall be had for the purposes of auditing the records of such applicant or licensee, securing compliance by such licensee with the provisions of this chapter, proving or disproving violation of any part of this chapter by any licensee, or to show payment or nonpayment of any taxes, fees, charges or the like due hereunder. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-210. - Copy of chapter. 
All licensees shall keep a copy of this chapter on the licensed premises and shall instruct any person working there about compliance with the terms hereof. Each licensee and the licensee's agents selling packaged malt beverages and/or wine, or selling for consumption on the premises malt beverages and/or wine, shall at all times be familiar with the terms hereof. The licensee shall be held responsible for any acts of the licensee's agents and employees which are in violation of this chapter, the statutory laws of the state, and/or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-211. - Posting of warnings. 
(a)  All licensees shall post in a conspicuous place in his or her establishment a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SALE OF BEER AND WINE TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS OF AGE STRICTLY PROHIBITED." 
(b)  All licensees shall post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "WARNING: DRINKING BEER AND WINE DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE BIRTH DEFECTS." 
(c)  Package licensees shall post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SALE OF BEER AND WINE ON SUNDAYS OTHER THAN BETWEEN THE HOURS OF 12:30 P.M. AND 11:30 P.M. STRICTLY PROHIBITED." 
(d)  Pouring licensees shall post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SERVICE OF BEER AND WINE ON SUNDAYS OTHER THAN BETWEEN THE HOURS OF 12:30 P.M. AND 12:00 MIDNIGHT STRICTLY PROHIBITED." 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013; Ord. No. 2014-06 , § II, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 6-212. - Prohibited sales. 
No licensee nor any agent or employee of a licensee shall furnish, sell or offer to sell any malt beverage and/or wine to any person who is confined in any jail, penal institution, correctional facility, prison camp, penitentiary or other lawful place of confinement, or to any person who is a patient or inmate of the Central State Hospital, or to any person who is noticeably intoxicated, or is of unsound mind, or is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to the licensee or the agent or employee. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-213. - Lock and key. 
All malt beverages and/or wine shall be under lock or fully covered by opaque material during those hours when their sale is not permitted except in the event of an emergency or under the direction of a law enforcement official, county official or his or her designate. All malt beverages and/or wine owned or possessed contrary to the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized by the proper authorities. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-214. - Containers. 
It shall be unlawful for licensees or their agents or employees to add to the contents of a container or to refill empty containers or in any manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any malt beverage and/or wine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-215—6-236. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 6-237. - Employee list; employment requirements. 
(a)  Every licensee under this chapter shall maintain at all times on the premises for which the license has been issued a list of all persons currently employed by such licensee at such premises, which list shall show the current full legal name, alias, date of birth, current address, current home telephone number and social security number of each employee. 
(b)  The employee list shall be available during reasonable hours for inspection by any law enforcement officer or county official or his or her designee. If so required by such person, an employee must submit to a fingerprint identification and criminal history check. Every licensee shall cause each of the licensee's employees during the hours of his or her employment to be identified by a conspicuous label or badge upon which shall appear the employee's first name. 
(c)  No person under 21 years of age shall be employed in any capacity in any place of business licensed under this section. No holder of a pouring license shall employ, require or permit a person under 21 years of age to sell or take orders for malt beverages and/or wine. However, persons under 21 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries and drugstores that are licensed to engage in the retail sale of malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages and not for consumption on the premises may sell or handle malt beverages and/or wine which are sold pursuant to and in compliance with this chapter. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to employ on the premises any person who, in the preceding ten years, has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state or who has been convicted of a crime outside the state which would be a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-238—6-267. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - MINORS 

Sec. 6-268. - Sale or possession of malt beverages and/or wine prohibited; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a minor to attempt to purchase malt beverages and/or wine or for any other person to purchase malt beverages and/or wine for a minor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a minor to exhibit fake, forged, or borrowed credentials in an effort to obtain malt beverages and/or wine to which the minor is not legally entitled. 
(c)  No person engaged in the business regulated hereunder shall make or permit to be made any sale of malt beverages and/or wine to minors. 
(d)  No person shall allow anyone under 21 years of age to loiter about the premises of the licensee or possess any alcoholic beverage. This provision shall not apply to employees over the age of 18 years eligible for subject employment under the laws of the state. 
(e)  Any violations of the provisions of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor and the offender, upon being found guilty, shall be punishable as for a misdemeanor, and by possible loss of license and fine. 
(f)  The prohibition contained in this subsection shall not apply with respect to the sale, purchase or possession of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption: 
(1)  For medical purposes pursuant to a prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in the state; 
(2)  At a religious ceremony; or 
(3)  In the minor's home with parental consent. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-269—6-299. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - VIOLATION AND DUE PROCESS 

Sec. 6-300. - Violations. 
(a)  Any violation of one or more provisions of this chapter shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-19, and shall be tried in the magistrate court as set forth in section 1-19. 
(b)  In addition to any punishment for violating this chapter, any such violation may subject a licensee to the revocation or suspension of his or her license, as set forth in sections 6-301 and 6-302. 
(1)  Any revocation or suspension based upon a violation of this chapter will subject the licensee to a reinstatement fee between $500.00 and $1,000.00, to be determined in the discretion of the board. 
a.  This reinstatement fee is nonrefundable and must be paid prior to the reinstatement of any license issued under this chapter. 
b.  No new license shall be issued to a licensee whose previous license was revoked or suspended until the reinstatement fee is paid. 
c.  Payment of the nonrefundable reinstatement fee does not guarantee the reinstatement or issuance of a license, but is instead a condition precedent to the consideration of reinstatement or issuance by the board. 
(2)  In addition to any other punishments or civil penalties set forth herein, any revocation or suspension based upon a violation of this chapter, may subject a licensee to the forfeiture of all stock of malt beverages and wine. 
(3)  The following suspension and revocation guidelines apply to a licensee who violates this chapter by selling or allowing the sale at his or her establishment of beer and/or wine to an ineligible individual under this chapter (including, but not limited to, a minor), sells during hours and/or days on which sales of beer and/or wine are prohibited under this chapter, and/or sells without a valid license, whether suspended, revoked, or not yet issued: 
a.  For a first offense within the previous five years, a 30-day suspension of his or her license and a reinstatement fee of $500.00. 
b.  For a second or subsequent offense within five years of a first offense, the revocation of his or her license for the remainder of the year, a reinstatement fee of $1,000.00, and forfeiture of all stock in malt beverages and wine. 
c.  These guidelines in subsections (1) and (2) above are those a licensee can expect to receive as a minimum, although the board will make the final decision in each instance and has the right to impose differing suspensions, revocations, and reinstatement fees. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-301. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the package sale of malt beverages and/or wine, or the sale of the same for consumption on the premises, in the unincorporated areas of the county without first complying with the rules and requirements set out in this chapter. Any license issued hereunder shall be subject to suspension or revocation upon any of the following grounds: 
(1)  The making of any false statement on an application for a license issued hereunder; 
(2)  A violation of the rules and regulations set out in this section and/or the laws and/or regulations of the United States and/or the state and/or the county; 
(3)  The failure to have the financial responsibility upon which issuance of the license was conditioned; 
(4)  Default in any obligation, of any kind whatsoever, lawfully owing to the county; 
(5)  Cancellation, suspension or revocation of a state malt beverage and/or wine license; 
(6)  Any violation of this section; or 
(7)  For any other legal and sufficient cause. 
(b)  In addition to the above-listed grounds for suspension or revocation, any pouring license issued hereunder shall be subject to suspension or revocation for a failure to meet the food/alcohol percentage requirement set in section 6-355 in any one calendar quarter. 
(c)  Any action taken by the board of commissioners to suspend or revoke a license issued hereunder shall not preclude and may be in addition to any fines and prosecution by a proper authority as provided by the laws and/or ordinances of the county, the state, and/or the United States and forfeiture of all stock of malt beverage and wine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-302. - Due process. 
(a)  Whenever the board of commissioners wishes to take any action to suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder, the board shall provide ten days' written notice, by personal service or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee prior to taking such action. The notice shall set forth the reasons for such action. The licensee shall have ten days from the date of receipt of such notification of such action (as set forth on the aforesaid receipt) to request a hearing before the board. Said notification shall be in writing and shall be delivered to the board by hand delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(b)  If a hearing is requested, the following information shall be given to the licensee, in writing, by regular mail to the licensee's last known address, at least ten days prior to the hearing date: 
(1)  A written copy of all charges or reasons for the proposed suspension or revocation; 
(2)  The date, time and location of the hearing, said hearing date to be not more than 20 days from the date of said written notice; 
(3)  A list of witnesses, if any, the board expects to testify or offer evidence in favor of the suspension or revocation; and 
(4)  Notice of the licensee's right to attend the hearing, to present evidence and testimony, to assert any defense, to confront and cross examine opposing witnesses, and to have an attorney present to represent the licensee. 
(c)  All decisions suspending or revoking a license shall set forth the reason for such action in writing, and shall be delivered to the licensee at his or her last known address by regular mail. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-303—6-322. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PACKAGE SALE OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-5-40 et seq., 3-5-80 et seq.; governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of wine, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-40 et seq., 3-6-60 et seq. 

Sec. 6-323. - Off-premises consumption. 
Malt beverages and/or wine sold pursuant to a package license granted under this chapter will be for consumption only off the premises of the licensee. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-324. - Annual license fee. 
The annual fee for a license shall be as per the schedule maintained in the office of the county building official and shall be paid after acceptance and approval of the application by the board of commissioners, but prior to the issuance of such license. The fee shall be paid either in cash or by bank certified check. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were granted. Licenses applied for after July 1 of each calendar year shall be prorated as per the schedule posted in the building and zoning department. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-325. - Regulations. 
(a)  No licensee shall sell or deliver any malt beverages and/or wine to any person except in the licensee's place of business. A licensee shall be permitted to load purchased goods in a customer's vehicle when the sale physically takes place and monies have been exchanged inside the place of business. A licensee may have a drive-in window and may deliver packaged malt beverages and/or wine through such window. Said drive-in window must be visible from the nearest street. "Curb service" type sales and sales to customers in vehicles parked in the parking area of the place of business are prohibited. 
(b)  No licensee shall furnish, sell or offer for sale any malt beverages and/or wine at any times except between 6:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. Monday through Saturday and between 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(c)  No person shall sell or possess for the purpose of sale, any malt beverages and/or wine where such person does not have a license from the board of commissioners to sell or possess for sale such malt beverages and/or wine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013; Ord. No. 2014-06 , § III, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 6-326. - Location and relocation. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49, no license shall be granted to any person authorizing the location of a new retail package liquor licensed place of business or the relocation of an existing retail package liquor licensed place of business engaged in the retail package sales of distilled spirits within 500 yards of any other business licensed to sell package liquor at retail, as measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-327. - Wholesale permits. 
Any wholesale distributor in malt beverages and wine licensed by the state or the agent of such licensed wholesale distributor may be granted a permit to distribute such malt beverages and wine in the county, upon application for such permit to the building official, and upon the presentation of evidence satisfactory to said county that the applicant understands and will comply with all terms and conditions and provisions of the chapter governing the package sale of malt beverages and wine in the county, as said chapter may be amended including, but not limited to, those under which malt beverages and wine licenses are issued, and upon payment of an annual fee of $100.00 for malt beverage wholesale distributors pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43, a fee of $200.00 for wine wholesale distributors and a fee of $300.00 for wholesale distributors of both beer and wine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-328. - Malt beverage taxes; distributor reports. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80 and O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81, there is hereby levied upon wholesale malt beverages distributors a tax on malt beverages as follows: 
(1)  Malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, shall be at a rate of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons, and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. 
(2)  When malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the board of commissioners a report itemizing all purchase invoices for malt beverages sold to each licensee in the county, on or before the tenth day of the month following such purchase. Said invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-329. - Wine taxes; exemptions; reports. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60, there is hereby levied on the first sale or use of wine by the package a tax of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the time rate on all fractional parts of a liter. Each month the first purchaser or user shall furnish to the board of commissioners a report itemizing each first purchase or use during the month. The report shall be furnished before the tenth day of the month following the month reported. The report shall show the amount of excise tax paid during the reported month. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-6-70 and O.C.G.A. § 3-6-71, no tax shall be levied by the board with respect to: 
(1)  Wine sold to and used by established and recognized churches and synagogues for use in sacramental services only; 
(2)  Any sale of wine which is exempt from taxation by the state or under the Constitution of the United States; 
(3)  Wine sold to persons outside this state for resale or consumption outside this state; or 
(4)  Wines which contain less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-330. - Financial responsibility. 
Any applicant for a license must show financial responsibility to the satisfaction of the board of commissioners. Financial statements must be submitted with each completed application as prescribed by the board. Any applicant who becomes licensed must maintain a minimum of $1,000.00 stock of goods while said license is held by said licensee. The stock shall be subject to inventory audit at the discretion of the board. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-331. - Transportation. 
(a)  All malt beverages transported or delivered to a licensee shall be packaged in the following manner, to-wit: seven-ounce, eight-ounce or 12-ounce sealed containers packaged four, six or 12 per package; 16-ounce sealed containers packaged six per package; 24-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the full case; 32-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the case; and draft beer in sealed containers which contain one-half barrel (15½ gallons), one-quarter barrel (seven and three-quarter gallons) or any other size as draft beer is normally sold, transported and delivered in sealed containers within the state. 
(b)  All wine transported or delivered to a licensee shall be packaged in containers specified in the standards of fill for wine prescribed by the Department of the Treasury of the United States for wines shipped in interstate commerce. The federal regulations relating to standards of fill for wine are adopted and incorporated by reference into this subsection. Wines manufactured and produced in the state shall be exempt from the provisions of this subsection to the extent that they are exempted from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-6-28, as amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 6-332—6-352. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SALE OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE FOR CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-5-40 et seq., 3-5-80 et seq.; governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of wine, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-40 et seq., 3-6-60 et seq.; local government may authorize issuance license to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on premises where sold, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-90 et seq. 

Sec. 6-353. - Unlawful sales without license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell any malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises without first complying with the rules and regulations set forth in this chapter. It shall be unlawful in any case for any person to sell or offer to sell any malt beverage and/or wine for consumption on the premises without first complying with this chapter. It shall be unlawful in any case for any person to sell or offer to sell any distilled spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(b)  A bed-and-breakfast home or inn may serve wine and/or malt beverages to its overnight guests without a license under this chapter so long as: 
(1)  The cost of the guests' lodging and meals exceeds the cost of alcohol provided; and 
(2)  No alcohol is provided to guests not staying at the bed-and-breakfast. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
State Law reference— Unlawful to knowingly or intentionally allow drinking of contents of alcoholic beverage on premises where sold without a license for consumption on the premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26. 
Sec. 6-354. - Additional application requirements. 
(a)  No malt beverages and/or wine shall be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises except under a pouring license granted by the board of commissioners. Application for such license may be made only on behalf of restaurants and private clubs located within the unincorporated areas of the county, and shall be made on forms provided by the board. 
(b)  Any application for a pouring license hereunder for a private club shall contain certified copies of all documents necessary for the board to ascertain that the applicant meets the requirements of a private club as defined in this chapter. 
(c)  All applicants for a pouring license must show financial responsibility. The board may require all applicants to provide financial statements and other evidence of financial responsibility in conjunction with the application. The form of the application shall be set by the board, and must be fully completed by the applicant and filed by the applicant with the building official. 
(d)  All pouring license applicants must be persons operating at the proposed licensed place of business a "restaurant" or "private club" as defined in this chapter. No lounges shall be permitted. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-355. - Food service requirements. 
Any sale of a food or beverage containing any malt beverage and/or wine shall be deemed to be a sale solely of a malt beverage and/or wine. A sales ratio of food sales to alcohol sales equal to or greater than 50 percent shall be maintained in order to meet the requirements for a pouring license. The fact that the sale of food during any calendar quarter is equal to or greater than the sales of malt beverages and/or wine shall not be conclusive that the licensee is meeting the requirements of operating a restaurant as defined in this chapter. However, the failure of the food sales to equal or exceed the sale of malt beverages and wine shall be prima facie evidence that the establishment is not meeting the definition of a restaurant. Any restaurant that sells malt beverages and/or wine shall have a food service permit issued by the Troup County Health Department. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-356. - On-premises consumption. 
No licensee may sell malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages or in any quantity for other than consumption on the premises. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-357. - Annual license fees. 
The annual fee for a malt beverage and wine pouring license shall be as per the schedule maintained in the office of the county building official and shall be paid after acceptance and approval of the application by the board of commissioners but prior to the issuance of such license. The fee shall be paid either in cash or by bank-certified check. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were granted. Licenses issued after July 1 of each calendar year shall be prorated according to the schedule posted in the building and zoning department 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-358. - Malt beverage taxes. 
(a)  Where malt beverages are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container as tap or draft beer, there is levied a state excise tax on malt beverages of $10.00 on each container sold containing not more than 31 gallons, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 31 gallons. 
(b)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans or other containers other than barrels or other bulk containers, a state excise tax of $0.045 per 12 ounces shall be collected, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts shall be collected. 
(c)  There is levied a state excise tax on all such beverages in excess of 576 ounces or two standard cases of 12-ounce size or the equivalent thereof or one, seven and three-quarter-gallon keg or barrel of such beverages, said tax being levied at the rate of taxation of $0.045 per 12 ounces. 
(d)  The board of commissioners shall impose an excise tax, in addition to the excise taxes levied by the state, as follows: 
(1)  Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more that 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons; 
(2)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any retail dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display, or sell any malt beverages on which such taxes have not been paid. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-359. - Wine taxes. 
(a)  There is levied and imposed on the first sale, use or final delivery within this state of all table wines a state excise tax in the amount of $0.11 per liter and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(b)  There is imposed upon the importation for use, consumption, or final delivery into this state of all table wines a state import tax in the amount of $0.29 per liter and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(c)  There is levied and imposed on the first sale, use or final delivery within this state of all dessert wines a state excise tax in the amount of $0.27 per liter and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(d)  There is imposed upon the importation for use, consumption, or final delivery into this state of all dessert wines a state import tax in the amount of $0.40 per liter and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(e)  There is hereby levied by the board of commissioners an excise tax on the first sale or use of wine by the package at the rate of $0.22 per liter and a proportional tax at the same rate for any fractional parts of a liter. 
(f)  The taxes imposed on wine shall not be levied on any wine sold to established and recognized churches and synagogues for use in sacramental services only, or for any wine exempt from taxation under the Constitution of the United States, or for any wine sold to persons for resale or consumption outside this state. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any retail dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display, or sell any wine on which such taxes have not been paid. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-360. - Soliciting. 
No retail licensee shall require, permit, suffer, encourage, or induce any employee or person to solicit in the licensed premises for himself or for any person other than the patron and guests of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any malt beverage and/or wine, or money with which to purchase the same; nor shall any licensee pay a commission or any other compensation to any person frequenting his or her establishment or to his or her agent or manager to solicit for himself or herself or for others, the purchase by the patron of malt beverage and/or wine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-361. - Delivery. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to make delivery of any malt beverage and/or wine except inside of the premises or area licensed for the sale thereof. It shall be unlawful for any such licensee to sell malt beverages and/or wine for consumption off the premises. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-362. - Promotions. 
No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall engage in any of the following practices in connection with the sale or other disposition of malt beverages and/or wine: 
(1)  The giving away of any ticket, token or any other item that can be exchanged for any malt beverage and/or wine upon the purchase of any other malt beverage and/or wine; 
(2)  The sale of two or more malt beverages and/or wine for a single price, or the sale of one serving of malt beverage and/or wine with a ticket, token or any other items redeemable for a subsequent serving of malt beverage and/or wine. Also prohibited hereunder is the sale of all such beverages a customer can or desires to drink at a single price. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-363. - Prohibited acts. 
No licensee shall authorize or permit any patron or customer to bring onto the premises one or more alcoholic beverages purchased elsewhere, nor shall any such licensee authorize or permit any patron or customer to take out of the premises one or more alcoholic beverages. No licensee shall authorize or permit any patron or customer to bring or carry any deadly weapon or firearm on the premises except a law enforcement officer or other person authorized by federal or state law to bring or carry any deadly weapon or firearm on the premises, nor shall the licensee act as a keeper, bailee or custodian of any kind of deadly weapon or firearm for any customer or patron. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-364. - Clearing service areas. 
All licensees shall remove or cause to be removed from the area of the premises utilized by the customers or patrons all malt beverages and/or wine within one-half hour after the time for last call specified in section 6-366[sic]. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-365. - Hours. 
No malt beverage and/or wine may be served before 8:00 a.m. or after 12:00 midnight Monday through Saturday, or on Sunday at any time other than between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013; Ord. No. 2014-06 , § IV, 6-3-2014) 
Secs. 6-366—6-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CATERING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Local government has authority to issue an off-premises license allowing alcoholic beverage caterer to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function, O.C.G.A. § 3-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 6-391. - Off-premises alcoholic beverage catering license. 
(a)  Any licensed alcoholic beverage caterer who holds a valid license from the county to sell: 
(1)  At a fixed location within the county, malt beverages or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises; or 
(2)  By the package for consumption off the premises; may be issued an off-premises license which authorizes such licensed alcoholic beverage caterer to distribute malt beverages and/or wine at an authorized catered function. 
(b)  Application for an off-premises license as provided herein shall be made to the building official upon forms to be prepared and approved by the board of commissioners. Applications will be decided according to the same rules and guidelines set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  The annual fee for an alcoholic beverage caterer's license shall be $100.00 annually for each licensed location. 
( Ord. No. 2014-02 , § I(Exh. A), 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 6-392. - Event permits. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverage caterer licensed by the county. In order to distribute malt beverages and/or wine at an authorized catered function, an alcoholic beverage caterer licensed by the county shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply for an event permit. The application shall include: 
a.  The name of the alcoholic beverage caterer, including the name of the specific representative of the caterer who will be responsible for, and present at, the catered function; 
b.  The date of the event; 
c.  The address of the event; 
d.  The time of the event; 
e.  The licensed alcoholic beverage caterer's license number; and 
f.  The name, address and phone number of the host of the catered function. No event permit fee shall be charged. 
(2)  Provide satisfactory reports to the state revenue commissioner on forms provided by that department, stating the quantity of any and all alcoholic beverages transported from the licensee's primary premises to the location of the authorized catered function and such other information as required by the commissioner. 
(3)  Maintain original local event permits and documents required by the state revenue department in the vehicle transporting the alcoholic beverages to the catered function at all times. 
(4)  Comply with all laws and ordinances regulating the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages, and no permit will be issued to any alcohol beverage caterer on probation or with a suspended license. 
(b)  Alcoholic beverage caterer licensed by other jurisdictions. In order to distribute malt beverages and/or wine at an authorized catered function, an alcoholic beverage caterer licensed by a subdivision of the state other than the county shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply for an event permit. The application shall include: 
a.  The name of the alcoholic beverage caterer, including the name of the specific representative of the caterer who will be responsible for, and present at, the catered function; 
b.  The date of the event; 
c.  The address of the event; 
d.  The time of the event; 
e.  The jurisdiction issuing the alcoholic beverage caterer's license; 
f.  The licensed alcoholic beverage caterer's license number; 
g.  A photocopy of the alcoholic beverage caterer's license; and 
h.  The name, address and phone number of the host of the catered function. 
(2)  Pay an event permit fee of $10.00; 
(3)  Pay local excise taxes that will be levied on the total quantity of alcoholic beverages brought into the county by the caterer, as calculated under this article, within 15 days of the conclusion of the catered event; 
(4)  Provide satisfactory reports to the state revenue commissioner on forms provided by that department, stating the quantity of any and all alcoholic beverages transported from the licensee's primary premises to the location of the authorized catered function and such other information as required by the commissioner; and 
(5)  Maintain original local event permits and documents required by the revenue department in the vehicle transporting the alcoholic beverages to the catered function at all times.
