(d)  It shall be a violation of this article and possible cause for revocation of operator's or employee's license for an employee, while semi-nude, to touch a patron or the clothing of a patron, or for a patron to touch a semi-nude employee or the clothing of a semi-nude employee, while said employee is on the premises of the sexually oriented business. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-53. - Regulations pertaining to exhibition of sexually explicit films and videos. 
(a)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, other than an adult motel, which exhibits on the premises in a viewing room of less than 150 square feet of floor space, a film, video cassette, or other video reproduction, that depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Upon application for a sexually oriented business license, the application shall be accompanied by a diagram of the premises showing a plan thereof specifying the location of one or more manager's stations and the location of all overhead lighting fixtures and designating any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. A manager's station may not exceed 32 square feet of floor area. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the business license will be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall be required and each diagram should be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale. The building official may waive the foregoing diagram for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of the premises has not been altered since said diagram was prepared. Certifying a previously approved diagram that proves to be false after visual inspection of the premises shall result in the suspension of a license until such time as diagram is submitted that is in conformance with this section. 
(2)  The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant. 
(3)  No alteration in the configuration or location of a manager's station may be made without the prior approval of the building official or his designee. 
(4)  It is the duty of the owners and operator of the premises to ensure that at least one employee is on duty and situated in each manager's station at all times that any patron is present inside the premises. 
(5)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from a manager's station of the entire area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose, excluding restrooms. Restrooms may not contain video reproduction equipment. If the premises has two or more manager's stations designated, then the interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view of the entire area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose from at least one of the manager's stations. The view required in this subsection must be by direct line of sight from the manager's station. 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the operator, and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises, to ensure that the view area specified in subsection (a)(5) remains unobstructed at all times. No doors, walls, partitions, curtains, merchandise, display racks, or other object shall obstruct from view of the manager's station any portion of the premises to which patrons have access. It shall be the duty of the operator, and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises, to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the premises that has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be permitted, as designated in the application filed pursuant to subsection (a)(1). 
(7)  The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access at an illumination of not less than five foot-candle as measured at the floor level. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of the operator, and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises, to ensure that the illumination described in subsection (a)(7) is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(9)  No viewing room or booth may be occupied by more than one person at any time. 
(10)  No opening of any kind shall exist between viewing rooms or booths. 
(11)  It shall be the duty of the operator, and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises, to ensure that no more than one person at a time occupies a viewing booth or room, and to ensure that no person attempts to make an opening of any kind between the viewing booths or rooms. 
(12)  The operator of the sexually oriented business shall, each business day, inspect the walls between the viewing booths to determine if any openings or holes exist. 
(13)  The operator of the sexually oriented business shall cause all floor coverings in viewing booths to be nonporous, easily cleanable surfaces, with no rugs or carpeting. 
(14)  The operator of the sexually oriented business shall cause all wall surfaces and ceiling surfaces in viewing booths to be constructed of, or permanently covered by, nonporous, easily cleanable material. No wood, plywood, composition board or other porous material shall be used within 48 inches of the floor. 
(b)  A person having a duty under subsection (a)(1)—(14) commits a misdemeanor if he/she, with knowledge, fails to fulfill that duty. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-54. - Exterior portions of sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner or operator of a sexually oriented business to allow the merchandise or activities of the establishment to be visible from a point outside the establishment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of a sexually oriented business to allow the exterior portion of the sexually oriented business to have flashing lights, or any words, lettering, photographs, silhouettes, drawings, or pictorial representations of any manner except to the extent permitted by the provisions of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of a sexually oriented business to allow exterior portions of the establishment to be painted any color other than a single achromatic color. This provision shall not apply to a sexually oriented business if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The establishment is a part of a commercial multiunit center; and 
(2)  The exterior portions of each individual unit in the commercial multiunit center, including the exterior portions of the business, are painted the same color as one another or are painted in such a way so as to be a component of the overall architectural style or pattern of the commercial multiunit center. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to require the painting of an otherwise unpainted exterior portion of a sexually oriented business. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-55. - Signage. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other county ordinance, code, or regulation to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any sexually oriented business or any other person to erect, construct, or maintain any sign for the sexually oriented business other than the one primary sign and one secondary sign, as provided in this section. 
(b)  Primary signs shall have no more than two display surfaces. Each such display surface shall: 
(1)  Not contain any flashing lights; 
(2)  Be a flat plane, rectangular in shape; 
(3)  Not exceed 64 square feet in area; and 
(4)  Not exceed ten feet in height or ten feet in length. 
(c)  Each letter forming a word on a primary sign shall be of solid color, and each such letter shall be the same print-type, size and color. The background behind such lettering on the display surface of a primary sign shall be of a uniform and solid color. 
(d)  Secondary signs shall have only one display surface. Such display surface shall: 
(1)  Be a flat plane, rectangular in shape; 
(2)  Not exceed 20 square feet in area; 
(3)  Not exceed five feet in height and four feet in width; and 
(4)  Be affixed or attached to any wall or door of the enterprise. 
(f)  The provisions of subsection (b)(1) and subsection (c) shall also apply to secondary signs. 
(g)  Any violation of any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalty as set forth in section 10-63. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-56. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
(a)  The sale, use, or consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises of a sexually oriented business is prohibited. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to the penalty as set forth in section 10-63 and reason for revocation of license. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-57. - Persons younger than 18 prohibited from entry; attendant required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to allow a person who is younger than 18 years of age to enter or be on the premises of a sexually oriented business at any time the sexually oriented business is open for business. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the operator of each sexually oriented business to ensure that an attendant is stationed at each public entrance to the sexually oriented business at all times during such sexually oriented business's regular business hours. It shall be the duty of the attendant to prohibit any person under the age of 18 years from entering the sexually oriented business. It shall be presumed that an attendant knew a person was under the age of 18 unless such attendant asked for and was furnished: 
(1)  A valid operator's, commercial operator's, or chauffeur's driver's license, or 
(2)  A valid personal identification certificate issued by the state reflecting that such person is 18 years of age or older. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to the penalty as set forth in section 10-63 and reason for revocation of license. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-58. - Sexual encounter centers. 
(a)  The board of commissioners makes the following specific findings with respect to sexual encounter centers that include live sex acts: 
(1)  The operation of a sexual encounter center for the purposes of providing the opportunity to engage in, or the opportunity to view, live sex acts is declared to be a disorderly house and a public nuisance per se, which should be prohibited; 
(2)  The operation of a sexual encounter center including live sex acts contributes to the spread of sexually transmitted diseases; and 
(3)  The operation of a sexual encounter center including live sex acts is inimical to the health, safety, general welfare and morals of the inhabitants of unincorporated [Troup] County, Georgia. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and maintain a sexual encounter center which includes live sex acts. 
(c)  Operation of a sexual encounter center that includes live sex acts is a public nuisance per se, and may be abated by order of the County Magistrate Court. 
(d)  The county building official and/or zoning administrator may apply upon behalf of the county to the magistrate court for an order permitting the county to abate violations of this section. 
(e)  After notice to the operator of a sexual encounter center including live sex acts, the magistrate judge shall conduct a hearing and take evidence as to whether a sexual encounter center including live sex acts is being operated in violation of this section. 
(f)  If, at the conclusion of the hearing, the magistrate judge determines that a sexual encounter center including live sex acts is being operated in unincorporated [Troup] County, Georgia in violation of this section, an order shall be entered authorizing the county to abate the violation by closing the business. A copy of the order shall be delivered to the operator of the sexual encounter center including live sex acts and mailed to the owner of the property upon which the sexual encounter center is located. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to any conduct that is otherwise exempted under this article or to the nonobscene presentation, showing or performance of any play; drama, or ballet in any theater; concert hall; fine arts academy; school; institution of higher education or similar establishment as a form of expression of opinion or communication of ideas or information, as differentiated from the promotion or exploitation of sex for the purpose of advancing the economic welfare of a commercial or business enterprise. This section applies whether or not it is a nonprofit or for profit business enterprise. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-59. - Hours of operation. 
No sexually oriented business, except for an adult motel, may remain open at any time between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 11:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays. No sexually oriented business shall open for business or remain open for business on Sunday or any legal holiday recognized by the state. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-60. - Exemptions. 
(a)  It is a defense to prosecution under this article that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in a modeling class operated: 
(1)  By a proprietary school, licensed by the state, a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
(2)  By a private college or university that maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this article, movies rated G, PG, PG-13, or R, NC-17, by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA), or live theatrical performances with serious artistic, social, or political value, that depict or describe specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities, are expressly exempted from regulation under this article. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-61. - Notices. 
(a)  Any notice required or permitted to be given by the building official or any other county office, division, department or other agency under this article to any applicant, operator or owner of a sexually oriented business may be given either by personal delivery or by certified United States Mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, addressed to the most recent address as specified in the application for the license, or any notice of address change that has been received by the building official. Notices mailed shall be deemed given upon their deposit in the United States Mail. In the event that any notice given by mail is returned by the postal service, the building official or his designee shall cause it to be posted at the principal entrance to the establishment. 
(b)  Any notice required or permitted to be given to the building official by any person under this article shall not be deemed given until and unless it is received in the office of the building official. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of each owner who is designated on the license application and each operator to furnish notice to the building official, in writing, of any change of residence or mailing address. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-62. - Injunction. 
A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business without a valid operator's license, or in violation of section 10-44, is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Each day a sexually oriented business so operates is a separate offense or violation. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-63. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating this article, or any provision hereof, upon conviction, shall be subject to the penalty or penalties as set forth in section 1-19 of the Code. 
(b)  No person accused of violating this chapter shall be arrested prior to trial, but any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate, and required to post a bond for his future appearance. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-64. - Court proceedings. 
(a)  Violations of this article shall be tried upon citations issued by the county and may be tried with or without a prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusations. 
(b)  Violations of this article shall be tried in the Magistrate Court of County, Georgia, and shall be tried in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq. 
(c)  Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-65. - Severability clause. 
In the event any court having jurisdiction shall declare any chapter, section, subsection or portion of this article unconstitutional or void, for any reason, all other articles, sections or subsections or parts not so declared unconstitutional or void shall remain in full force and effect and shall be enforceable. 
( Ord. No. 2009-07 , § I(Exh. A), 2-17-2009) 
Secs. 10-66—10-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMUSEMENT CENTERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-171. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement center means an establishment primarily engaged in the commercial operation of jukeboxes, mechanical amusement devices, or similar type equipment as an amusement and recreational service to the general public. An amusement center shall be considered any establishment, which has five or more mechanical amusement devices for commercial operation on the premises. 
Jukebox means any machine, contrivance or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc or key into a slot, crevice, or other opening, or upon the payment of a price in any manner, operates or may be operated, for the emissions of songs, music or similar amusement. 
Mechanical amusement device means any machine, contrivance or device which may be activated or which is permitted to function by the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, or upon the payment of a price in any manner and which is operated for amusement only, and does not give or offer to give in any manner any form of payoff, prize or reward; a pool or billiard table is excluded from this definition. 
(Code 1987, § 5-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 10-172. - Exemption. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to any amusement device use in the home of the owner thereof and operated solely for personal noncommercial use. 
Sec. 10-173. - Possession, sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages within licensed premises. 
No person holding a license for operation of an amusement center under this article shall permit the possession, sale, offer for sale, or consumption of any alcoholic beverage within or on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1987, § 5-7(a)) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
Sec. 10-174. - Proximity to church or school. 
No person shall operate an amusement center within 300 feet of the nearest property line of a church or public or private primary or secondary school. 
(Code 1987, § 5-7(b)) 
Sec. 10-175. - Hours of operation. 
No person shall operate an amusement center other than between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Monday through Saturday, and 1:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
(Code 1987, § 5-7(c)) 
Sec. 10-176. - Gambling. 
Nothing in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling device or machine in violation of the laws of the state or of the United States of America, or to authorize, license or permit to be on the premises any machine or mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device or which is in any way contrary to the laws of the state or of the United States of America. 
(Code 1987, § 5-7(e)) 
Secs. 10-177—10-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-201. - Required. 
The operation of an amusement center within the county shall be unlawful unless an application shall be made and a license therefor issued, pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 5-2) 
Sec. 10-202. - Application. 
Any person desiring to secure the issuance of a license for the operation of an amusement center shall make application to the business license department for issuance of a license, and such application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, address, age and date and place of birth of the applicant; 
(2)  Any prior convictions of the applicant or violation of any municipal, county, state or federal laws, except parking violations; 
(3)  The place where the amusement center is to be licensed and operated; and 
(4)  The length of time applicant has been a resident of the county. 
(Code 1987, § 5-3) 
Sec. 10-203. - Investigation of applicant. 
The sheriff shall make an investigation to ascertain if the applicant is of good moral character and shall investigate the proposed location of such amusement center and, upon completion of such investigation, shall recommend either approval or disapproval of such application, and submit the findings of such investigation and the recommendation to the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1987, § 5-4) 
Sec. 10-204. - Consideration of application; issuance. 
(a)  The board of commissioners, at its next regular meeting after receiving the investigation report of the sheriff, shall consider the application, the investigation and recommendation of the sheriff and determine whether the license shall be issued or shall be refused. 
(b)  Upon approval by the board of commissioners, a license shall be issued to the applicant for the operation of an amusement center at the location revealed in the application for license upon a payment of the license fee provided in section 10-47. 
(Code 1987, § 5-5) 
Sec. 10-205. - Revocation. 
The county expressly reserves the right to revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, if the licensee shall directly or indirectly permit the operation of an amusement center contrary to the provisions of this article, the other ordinances of the county or the laws of the state or of the United States of America. If, after issuance of a license, the county desires to revoke such license, written notice thereof shall be given to the licensee, such notice to specify the violation with which the licensee is charged, and shall specify a date and time and place at which a hearing upon such revocation shall be heard. The licensee shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, shall have the right to be represented by counsel, and shall have the right to introduce and submit evidence in opposition to such revocation. The decision of the board of commissioners shall be based upon evidence submitted at such hearing. 
(Code 1987, § 5-6) 
Secs. 10-206—10-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL OR BILLIARD ROOMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to license, tax and regulate billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2. 

Sec. 10-241. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue, and shall include all forms of the games known as "carom billiards," "pocket billiards" and "English billiards." 
Poolroom and billiard room mean any public place where a person is permitted to play the game of pool or billiards and for which a charge is made for use of equipment. 
(Code 1987, § 5-39) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 10-242. - License. 
(a)  Required. The operation of a poolroom or billiard room within the county or within any municipality lying within the county shall be unlawful unless an application shall be made and a license therefor issued, pursuant to the provisions of this article and the other provisions of this Code and laws. 
(b)  Qualifications of applicants. The qualifications for any license applicant pursuant to this article shall be the same as those qualifications as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 43-8-3, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(c)  Application. Any person desiring to secure the issuance of a license for the operation of a pool room or billiard room shall make application in the office of the county business license department and such application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, address, age and date and place of birth of the applicant; 
(2)  Any prior convictions of applicant or violation of any municipal, county, state or federal laws, except parking violations; 
(3)  The place where the poolroom or billiard room is to be licensed and operated; and 
(4)  The length of time applicant has been a resident of the county. 
(d)  Filing of affidavit, surety bond and transfer of ownership of licensed billiard room or poolroom. Every application for a license issued pursuant to this article shall be accompanied by an affidavit and bond as required in O.C.G.A. § 43-8-5, as the same may be amended from time to time. Any transfer of a licensed billiard room shall likewise be subject to the requirements of such state law. 
(Code 1987, §§ 5-40—5-43) 
Sec. 10-243. - Requirements of operation. 
Any poolroom or billiard room licensed pursuant to this article shall be subject to and operated in accordance with the requirements of state law as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq., as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 5-44) 
Sec. 10-244. - Sale or use of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold for consumption on the premises, served, or allowed to be used in or on the premises of any poolroom or billiard room located in the unincorporated area of the county or any place operated in connection therewith. 
(b)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold for consumption on the premises, served, or allowed to be used in or on the premises of any poolroom or billiard room located within any municipality in the county except as allowed under the provisions of state law found in O.C.G.A. § 43-8-12, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, however, it shall be lawful to sell alcoholic beverages at retail on the premises in which a pool or billiard table is located, provided that the owner and/or manager of such retail establishment takes the steps necessary to ensure that the alcoholic beverages sold are not consumed on the premises. 
(Code 1987, § 5-45) 
Secs. 10-245—10-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 10-281. - Declaration of policy. 
The county board of commissioners does hereby declare that a license for an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment shall not be granted until an application has first been submitted to the county board of commissioners as set forth in this article and that the license shall not be granted if the applicant has been convicted of a felony involving moral turpitude unless it appears to the satisfaction of the county board of commissioners that the licensed premises will be operated in a lawful manner, in which case the board of commissioners may, in their discretion issue such license. 
(Code 1987, § 5-56) 
Sec. 10-282. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Entertainment I establishment, means any establishment which for profit holds dances with music provided by either mechanical or live means and in which establishment a location is specified and designated for dancing. 
Entertainment II establishment, means any establishment, other than an adult dancing establishment or previously defined in this Code, wherein music is provided as a part of a for-profit enterprise but in which dancing is not normally expected to occur and in which no designated area is provided for dancing. This shall include, but not be limited to, music concerts and supper club operations. The presence and use of a juke-box or karaoke machine shall not, in and of itself, render an establishment an entertainment II establishment subject to the provisions of this Article so long as such presence and use is incidental to the operation of the establishment and no separate fee or charge is made based upon such presence or use. 
(Code 1987, § 5-57; Ord. No. 2008-04, § I, 5-20-2008) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 10-283. - License. 
(a)  Application. Every person making application for a license to engage in the business of operating an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment shall make application to the county board of commissioners and the application shall contain: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant and the length of his residence within the state; 
(2)  The address and place for which such license is desired; 
(3)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the business licensed is to be located; 
(4)  A statement that the applicant intends to carry on the business for himself or under his immediate supervision and direction; and 
(5)  A statement that the applicant is of good moral character and has never been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
The application must be verified by the applicant before a notary public or other person duly authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(b)  Fees. Each entertainment I establishment subject to the terms of this section shall pay an annual fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county business license department. Each entertainment II establishment subject to the terms of this section shall pay an annual fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the county business license department. If an establishment's activities can be considered to constitute both an entertainment I and entertainment II establishment, it shall pay an annual fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the county business license department. 
(c)  Investigation of applicant. 
(1)  The sheriff shall make an investigation to ascertain if the applicant is of good moral character and shall investigate the proposed location of such. Upon completion of such investigation, the sheriff shall recommend either approval or disapproval of the application and submit his investigation report and recommendation to the board of commissioners. 
(2)  After receiving an application for the issuance of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment license, the building official for the county will conduct an investigation for the purpose of determining whether the proposed location complies with both church and school boundaries. Further, the building official will be responsible for giving the proper notice requirements as specified in this section for the holding of a public hearing as well as having a sign placed on the property at least 15 days prior to the holding of a public hearing indicating that an application has been made for the issuance of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment license. 
(d)  Consideration of application; issuance. 
(1)  After receiving the investigation report of the sheriff, the board of commissioners shall hold a first public hearing on all applications for entertainment I or entertainment II establishments. Notice of the time and place shall be published at least 15 days, but not more than 45 days, before the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. The notice shall include the name of the applicant and the location of the property where the entertainment I or entertainment II establishments or other similar establishment is to be located. A sign showing that an application has been made for the issuance of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment license shall be placed in a conspicuous location on the property at least 15 days prior to the hearing. 
(2)  The board of commissioners shall conduct a public hearing at the designated time, and members of the public shall have an opportunity to appear and express any concerns or objections relating to the application. No vote on the application will be taken by the board of commissioners at this initial public hearing. 
(3)  At the second scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners following the initial public hearing, a second public hearing on the application shall be held. The application shall be read and members of the public shall again have an opportunity to appear and express any concerns or objections relating to the application. At the conclusion of this second public hearing, the application shall be considered by the board of commissioners and a determination shall be made as to whether the license shall be issued or denied. 
(4)  Upon approval by the board of commissioners, a license shall be issued to the applicant for the operation of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment at the location revealed in the application for license upon a payment of the license fee provided in section 50-47 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(5)  Applications for entertainment I and entertainment II establishment licenses shall not be submitted more than once in a 12-month period, unless the applicant can show that the conditions upon which denial was based have substantially changed. The mere fact that a change in ownership or management, in and of itself, shall not be considered as a substantially changed condition. 
(Code 1987, §§ 5-58—5-60) 
Sec. 10-284. - Unlawful acts on licensed premises. 
(a)  No person will be allowed to sell malt beverages or wine in the operation of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment without complying completely and fully with the provisions regulating alcoholic beverages contained in chapter 6 of this Code. 
(b)  No person holding a license for the operation of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment shall permit the consumption of any malt beverages or wine within or on the licensed premises unless the operator is in a legitimate restaurant business which has been approved and licensed by the state and permitted by the county health department. For the purposes of this section, the term "restaurant" is defined as a place where the serving of full-course meals to the public is its principal business and is more than a place where short-order sandwiches and snacks are sold, and the business must have the capacity to seat a minimum of 50 people inside the premises. 
(c)  No person shall operate an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment within 300 feet of the nearest property line of a church or public or private primary or secondary school. 
(d)  No person shall operate an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment other than between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday and Saturday from 8:00 a.m. until 12:00 midnight. Further, such a business operation is prohibited from operating on Sunday. 
(Code 1987, § 5-61) 
Sec. 10-285. - Revocation of license. 
The county expressly reserves the right to revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article if the license shall directly or indirectly permit the operation of an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment contrary to the provisions of this article, the other ordinances of the county or the laws of the state or of the United States of America. If, after issuance of a license, the county desires to revoke such license, written notice thereof shall be given to the licensee, such notice to specify the violation with which the licensee is charged, and shall specify a date and time and place at which a hearing upon such revocation shall be heard. The licensee shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, shall have the right to be represented by counsel, and shall have the right to introduce and submit evidence in opposition to such revocation. The decision of the board of commissioners shall be based upon evidence submitted at such hearing. 
(Code 1987, § 5-62) 
Sec. 10-286. - Penalties for violation of article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating an entertainment I or entertainment II establishment or other similar establishment without first obtaining a license therefor. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-19 of this Code. 
(Code 1987, § 5-63) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), adopted Nov. 17, 2006, repealed the former Art. I, §§ 14-1—14-11, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1987, §§ 6-1—6-10. 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned animals means any domesticated animal which shall have been placed upon public property or within a public building unattended or uncared for, or upon or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or tenant of such property unattended or uncared for. Any domesticated animal shall also be considered abandoned which shall have been upon or within the property of the owner or custodian of such animal unattended and without food and water for any period of time sufficient to create a danger to the health of such animal. 
Aggressive dog or animal, vicious dog or animal, or potentially aggressive or vicious dog or animal means any dog or other animal that: 
(1)  Has caused physical injury to humans or domestic animals without provocation, whether on public or private property; 
(2)  Because of temperament, conditioning, or training, has the propensity, tendency or disposition to attack, bite, or injure humans or domestic animals without provocation; 
(3)  Aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after it has been classified as a potentially dangerous animal and after the owner has been notified of such classification; or 
(4)  Causes reasonable fear of bodily injury to any person by attacking or threatening to attack such person. 
(5)  For purposes of this definition and article, an animal which is defending itself or its owner or keeper from attack shall be deemed to have been "provoked." 
Animal means any domesticated or wild creature, including fowl, fish and reptiles. 
Animal at large means any animal not under restraint and off the property of its owner. 
Animal control department means the department established by the board of commissioners charged with enforcing the provisions of this article. 
Animal under restraint means an animal controlled by a leash or lead; an animal while off the property of the owner at "heel" beside a competent person and obedient to that person's commands; an animal while on the property of the owner in the presence of a competent person and obedient to that person's commands; an animal confined on or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets; an animal in a building or fenced area within the property limits of its owner or keeper. 
Animal shelter means any premises designated by the board of commissioners for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals found in violation of this article and for unwanted animals. 
Cage means a facility designed to incarcerate a specific species of animal within a limited area. 
Domesticated animal means any animal, bird, or reptile, of any species, which is owned, kept, harbored or maintained as a household pet, for food production, or for other purposes. 
Fenced area means any area enclosed by a fence of such height and strength as to reasonably prevent an animal from leaving such area. 
Kennel pet shop means any building or area used for the keeping, breeding, buying, selling, exhibiting and/or boarding of wild or domesticated animals commercially. 
Nuisance means any animal which: 
(1)  Is an abandoned or stray animal; 
(2)  Is a female dog or cat running at large when in heat; 
(3)  Is an unlicensed and untagged dog or cat; 
(4)  Engages without provocation in incessant or untimely barking or other noise making in such a manner as to reasonably disturb any person or neighborhood. For purposes of this definition and article, an animal which barks as the result of the intentional and unauthorized actions of persons other than the owner or custodian of the animal shall be deemed to have been "provoked;" 
(5)  Destroys property belonging to others; 
(6)  Habitually chases passing persons or vehicles; 
(7)  Is a vicious animal; or 
(8)  Causes unsanitary conditions. 
Owner means any person owning, keeping, selling or harboring any animal. 
Permit means an application form provided by the health department which must be completed and approved by the health department for the purpose of obtaining a county business license to commercially keep, breed, buy, sell, exhibit or board animals. 
Shelter means any type of sound structure which provides cover and protection from the wind, rain, heat and cold. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § I, 7-7-2009; Ord. No. 2011-04 , §§ I, II, 5-17-2011) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 14-2. - Animal control department. 
(a)  Created; staffing. There is hereby created the county animal control department which shall have primary responsibility for animal control in the unincorporated areas of the county. Such department shall be staffed by such employees as may be deemed feasible and appropriate from time to time by the board of commissioners, taking into account the need for such employees and available budgetary resources. 
(b)  Responsibility and duties. The animal control department shall have the following responsibilities and duties: 
(1)  Be responsible for the operation of any animal control shelter which may be established by the board of commissioners and the performance of such duties and the keeping of such records related to animal control and welfare as the board of commissioners may require. 
(2)  Cooperate with the health department in the enforcement of rabies control regulations and animal control directives. 
(3)  Cooperate with the county humane society. 
(4)  Pick up and impound animals which are in violation of this article. 
(5)  Prosecute in the county magistrate court, as well as any appeals therefrom, any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § II, 7-7-2009) 
Sec. 14-3. - Animal shelter. 
The board of commissioners may construct or otherwise create or designate an animal shelter for the purpose of caring for and disposing of animals impounded by the animal control department in accordance with this article and for receiving unwanted animals. The board of commissioners may also contract with any person, including, any other governmental entity or agency, for the creation or operation of such an animal shelter. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
Sec. 14-4. - Rabies inoculation. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep or harbor a dog or cat within the unincorporated limits of the county unless such animal has been vaccinated against rabies in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state department of human resources and the county department of health. 
(b)  The owner or custodian of such dog or cat shall retain in such person's possession a certificate of vaccination or other written proof that such animal has been given a current vaccination. 
(c)  The owner or custodian of any such dog shall also be responsible for obtaining a numbered vaccination tag furnished or approved by the state department of human resources at the time of such vaccination, which shall be affixed to a collar worn by the dog at all times the dog is off the premises of the owner. Cats and dogs while the same are on the premises of the owner, are not required to wear a rabies tag, but the owner shall have written proof of current vaccination. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination tag to the collar of any animal for which it was not issued, or to remove a vaccination tag from any animal without the consent of the owner or custodian. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2011-04 , § III, 5-17-2011) 
State Law reference— Rabies control, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-5. - Report of animal bites; confinement of animal. 
Any person bitten by or discovering or reasonably suspecting any domestic animal to be suffering with rabies shall immediately report such fact to the department of health, giving the name and address of the owner or custodian of such dog. It shall be the duty of the owner or custodian of such animal to confine such animal in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state department of human resources and the county department of health. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
Sec. 14-6. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Causes. The animal control department shall be authorized to take possession of and impound any of the following: 
(1)  Any dog running at large or free from restraint without a current vaccination tag. 
(2)  Any wild dog. 
(3)  Any abandoned animal or domestic animal the ownership of which is unknown. 
(4)  Any animal having rabies or reasonably suspected of having rabies if the owner or custodian of such animal refuses or fails to confine such animal as required by applicable rules, regulations or laws. 
(5)  Any domestic animal in heat running at large or free from restraint other than within the limits of the property of the owner or custodian of such dog. 
(6)  Any domestic animal which is running at large or free from restraint other than within the limits of the property of the owner of such animal. 
(7)  Any animal in which the condition or the treatment of the animal is causing unnecessary pain and suffering. 
(b)  Disposition of animals. Any dogs or other animals impounded by the animal control department pursuant to this article may be disposed of in a humane manner as detailed in the following subsections: 
(1)  Animals delivered to the animal shelter by their owners residing within the limits of the unincorporated areas of the county shall be made available for adoption immediately. If not adopted, the animals shall be euthanized at the end of a ten-day (240-hour) period. 
(2)  Animals delivered to the animal shelter by persons other than their owners residing within the limits of the unincorporated areas of the county are to be retained for a period of four days (96 hours) as a redeeming period and an additional six days (144 hours) as an adoption period. The first four days (96 hours) shall be sufficient time for owners to redeem an animal. The six additional days (144 hours) shall be a period for adoption. 
(3)  The euthanizing of sick, injured or vicious animals shall be at the discretion of the director of the animal shelter. The date and time that the sick, injured or vicious animal is euthanized shall be at the discretion of the animal control department or the person in charge of the shelter. 
(c)  Redemption. The owner or lawful custodian shall be entitled to claim and obtain possession of any impounded dog or other animal at any time before the expiration of such period upon compliance with the vaccination requirements of this article and payment of all applicable fees. Any animal impounded under this section may be reclaimed as provided in this section upon the payment by the owner or the custodian of any fee which may be imposed, from time to time, by the board of commissioners by resolution. In addition, the owner or lawful custodian shall pay the cost of any required vaccinations. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
Sec. 14-7. - Animal roaming free. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner to: 
(1)  Fail to keep their animal from running at large or under restraint; 
(2)  Fail to confine their animal having rabies or reasonably suspected of having rabies. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
Sec. 14-8. - Nuisance animals. 
In addition and supplementary to any other requirements and prohibitions of this article or this Code, it shall be unlawful and deemed a public nuisance and separate violation for any owner to: 
(1)  Fail to keep their female dog or cat from running at large or under restraint when in heat. 
(2)  Fail to keep their dog from engaging in incessant or untimely barking or other noise making in such a manner as to reasonably disturb any person or neighborhood. It shall not be a violation of this subpart if the owner or custodian of the dog shows by clear and convincing evidence that the incessant or untimely barking complained of was caused or substantially contributed to by the intentional acts of third parties. 
(3)  Fail to keep their animal from destroying property belonging to others. 
(4)  Fail to keep their animal from habitually chasing passing persons or vehicles. 
(5)  Fail to keep their animal from causing unsanitary conditions. 
(6)  Abandon any domesticated animal within unincorporated Troup County, Georgia. 
(7)  Fail to prevent their animal from becoming a nuisance animal as defined in section 14-1 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § III, 7-7-2009; Ord. No. 2011-04 , § IV, 5-17-2011) 
Sec. 14-9. - Aggressive, vicious, or potentially aggressive or vicious dogs. 
(a)  No person owning or having custody or control of any dog or other animal known by such person to be aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious shall permit it to run at large, or permit it to run loose on or within the premises of such person in such a manner as to endanger the life or limb of any person lawfully entering such premises. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal, or anyone having any such animal in his possession or custody, to ensure that such animal is kept under restraint, as prescribed in subsections (d), (e) and (f) of this section and that reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent the animal from leaving, while unattended, the real property limits of its owner, custodian, or harborer, and it is securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, locked pen, or other enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump, or otherwise escape on its own volition. Such enclosure must be securely locked at any time the animal is left unattended so that children are prevented from entry and to prevent the animal from escaping. 
(c)  For owners of an aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal which lives out-of-doors, a portion of their property should be fenced with a perimeter or area fence. Within this perimeter fence, the animal must be humanely confined inside a locked pen or kennel of adequate size. The kennel or pen must have secure sides that set securely into the ground or onto a concrete pad. The gate to the kennel must be locked when the animal is unattended. This enclosure shall provide protection from the elements. 
(d)  An aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal shall not be upon any street or public place except when securely restrained by a leash not more than six feet in length and humanely muzzled and in the charge of a competent person. 
(e)  Whenever outside of its enclosure, as provided for in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, but on the owner's property, an aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal must be attended by the owner or custodian and restrained by a secure collar, muzzled when appropriate, as determined by the animal control officer, and on a leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(f)  No aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied while unattended by the owner or custodian to any inanimate object such as a tree, post, or building outside of its primary enclosure. 
(g)  A warning sign (e.g., beware of dog) shall be conspicuously posted denoting an aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive animal on the premises. 
(h)  Failure to keep any aggressive, vicious or potentially aggressive or vicious animal confined or under restraint as provided for in this section shall be unlawful and shall be punishable as provided in this article. 
(i)  In the event any person is cited for and convicted of a violation of this section, the animal shall be registered with the Animal Control Department. The annual fee for the registration shall be $500.00. The animal shall be registered annually so long as it is located in unincorporated Troup County. At the time of registration and annually thereafter when the registration is renewed, an animal control officer shall require evidence from the owner and make investigation as may be necessary to verify that the animal is confined as provided in this section and that the owner, keeper, responsible person or custodian is in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(j)  In the event any person is cited for and convicted of a violation of this section and the animal is further determined by the Magistrate Court to be of a breed, size, predisposition, temperament or nature so as to be capable of causing serious and permanent physical injury, the Magistrate Court shall be authorized to order the person owning or controlling or in possession of the animal to maintain as an additional registration requirement either (1) a policy of insurance in the amount of at least $50,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the animal against liability for personal injuries inflicted by the animal; or (2) a surety bond in the amount of $50,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state and payable to any person injured by the animal. 
(k)  Violation of the registration requirements of this section shall be punishable as provided in chapter 1, section 1-19 of the Code of Troup County, Georgia, and each day any such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, violation of the registration requirements of this section shall subject the unregistered animal(s) to seizure and impoundment by the Animal Control Department. Any animal so impounded shall be retained for ten days, during which time the owner may reclaim the animal upon proof of compliance with this section, proof of vaccination requirements of this article, and payment of the redemption fee and/or cost of any required vaccinations as provided in subsection 14-6(c) of this article. If the owner of the impounded animal is known, such owner shall be notified of the impoundment. Should the owner fail to reclaim the animal within ten days from impoundment, the animal shall be euthanized. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2011-04 , § V, 5-17-2011) 
Editor's note— Section V of Ord. No. 2011-04 , adopted May 17, 2011, changed the title of § 14-9 from "Vicious dogs" to "Aggressive, vicious, or potentially aggressive or vicious dogs." 
Sec. 14-10. - Restraint of animals. 
(a)  The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this code section, unless otherwise specifically stated: 
Leash or lead means a rope, chain, cord, strap or webbing, cable or similar device that is attached to an animal's collar or harness for purposes of restraining the animal and is held by or attached to a competent person. 
Swivel means pivoting hardware that can be used in a trolley system to attach a cable run to a tether or a tether to an animal's collar or harness in order to minimize twisting and tangling of the tether. 
Tether means a rope, chain, cord, strap or webbing, cable or similar device that is attached to an animal's collar or harness for purposes of restraining the animal. 
Trolley system means a method of restraining an animal which utilizes a cable run, swivel and tether attached to an animal's collar or harness. 
(b)  No animal may be restrained by tether in such a manner as to subject it to unreasonable pain, stress or risk of tangling and choking. 
(c)  The only manner that any dog may be physically restrained outdoors, other than by leash or lead or fenced area, shall be by a trolley system in which the tether: 
(1)  Is attached to a properly fitting collar, which may not be a choke collar, pinch collar, prong collar or similar device, or harness worn by the dog; and 
(2)  Is ten feet in length or five times the length of the dog, measured from the tip of the dog's nose to the base of its tail, whichever is greater. 
( Ord. No. 2018-11 , § I, 11-21-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-11 , § I, adopted Nov. 21, 2017, repealed § 14-10 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former § 14-10 pertained to tethering of animals, and derived from Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), adopted Nov. 17, 2006. 
Sec. 14-11. - Humane care of animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to overload, maim, tease, torture, abuse or kill any animal. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of shelter which shall protect the animal from the elements. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of necessary medical attention when the animal is in a condition in which failure to provide medical attention would result in death or unreasonable pain or suffering. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of sufficient food and water as often as the feeding habits of such animal require to prevent dehydration, starvation or a significant risk to the animal's health from lack of food or water. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the county for the purpose of harming any domesticated animal. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to release or leave any animal on any private or public property with the intention of abandoning such animal. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
Sec. 14-12. - Penalties for violation. 
Violations of this article shall be punishable by and subject to the penalties as provided in Chapter 1, Section 1-19 of the Code of Troup County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § I(Exh. A), 11-17-2006) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20. 
Secs. 14-13—14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-04, § II(Exh. A), adopted Nov. 17, 2006, set out provisions intended for use as Art. II, §§ 14-13—14-15. At the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Art. II, §§ 14-26—14-28. 

Sec. 14-26. - Implementation of state law. 
This article shall be known and may be referred to as the Responsible Dog Ownership Ordinance of Troup County. It is the intention of the board of commissioners of Troup County by the adoption of this article to fully implement the provisions of the Responsible Dog Ownership Law adopted and approved by the General Assembly of Georgia on May 3, 2012, and made effective, for enforcement purposes on July 1, 2012, as the same now exists or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § II(Exh. A, § 14-13), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2013-01 , § I, 7-17-2012) 
Sec. 14-27. - Animal control board for dangerous and potentially dangerous dog control. 
The Troup County Animal Control Board for Dangerous and Potentially Dangerous Dog Control created by resolution of the county board of commissioners dated February 15, 2011, shall hear and determine the matters provided for in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23. The membership and terms of members of the Troup County Animal Control Board for Dangerous and Potentially Dangerous Dog Control shall be as is provided from time to time by the board of commissioners. The animal control board for dangerous and potentially dangerous dog control shall meet once each January and at any other time during the year that the county dog control officer may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § II(Exh. A, § 14-14), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § IV, 7-7-2009; Res. No. 2011-13 , 2-15-2011; Ord. No. 2013-01 , § II, 7-17-2012) 
Editor's note— Res. No. 2011-13 , adopted Feb. 15, 2011, changed the title of § 14-27 from "Animal control board" to "Animal control board for dangerous and potentially dangerous dog control." 
Sec. 14-28. - Dog control officer. 
The position of Troup County Dog Control Officer as created by resolution of the Troup County Board of Commissioners dated October 4, 1988, shall be continuously filled by an individual appointed by the county manager to fill such position. Such individual shall carry out the duties and responsibilities of the dog control officer as provided in the Responsible Dog Ownership Law of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04, § II(Exh. A, § 14-15), 11-17-2006; Ord. No. 2013-01 , § III, 7-17-2012) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 
Secs. 14-29—14-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL KEEPING, SALE OR DISPLAY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Formerly, Article II. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-41. - Jurisdiction of article provisions. 
This article shall apply to the unincorporated area of the county. 
(Code 1987, § 6-20) 
Sec. 14-42. - Interpretation of article provisions. 
This article is not intended to annul any state or federal law, or other agreement between parties. However, where this article imposes a greater restriction upon the owner or permittee, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Code 1987, § 6-21) 
Sec. 14-43. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall possess, buy, sell or display, commercially, any animal without a permit therefor from the county. 
(b)  Exemptions. The occasional buying or selling of horses, cattle, sheep, hogs, and other domesticated animals (including dogs and cats) as an accessory to a normal farm operation shall be exempt from the provisions of this article requiring a permit. 
(c)  Information furnished with application. The applicant, when applying for a permit, shall furnish the health department with a list of the kinds of animals to be kept, handled or exhibited, with the estimated maximum number included at any one time. 
(Code 1987, §§ 6-22—6-24) 
Sec. 14-44. - Care of animals. 
In all establishments operated under a permit under this article, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  All animals must be supplied with sufficient, good and wholesome food and water as often as the feeding habits of such animals require. 
(2)  All animals and animal quarters shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. Adequate ventilation shall be maintained. 
(3)  Proper shelter and protection from the weather shall be provided and maintained for all animals at all times. Animals must not be overcrowded, nor exposed to excessive heat or cold. Quarters shall be draft free. Proper temperature for the well-being of the animals shall be maintained at all times. 
(4)  Animals shall not be without care and attention by the permittee. 
(5)  The permittee shall use every reasonable precaution to ensure that animals are not teased, abused, mistreated, tormented or in any manner made to suffer by any person or by any means. 
(6)  The permittee shall not maintain, nor permit to exist, any condition that is or could be, injurious to the animals. 
(7)  Animals which are worked, kept for sale or exhibited shall be healthy and in good condition of flesh. 
(8)  Animals which are enemies by nature, of other animals, or are temperamentally unsuited, shall not be quartered with such other animals, nor so near thereto as to cause fear in any such animals, or to cause any animal to be abused or tormented. 
(9)  Animals shall be maintained in quarters so constructed as to prevent their escape. The permittee assumes full responsibility for recapturing any animal that escapes from such person's premises. The permittee shall take all reasonable precautions to protect the public from the animals and the animals from the public. 
(10)  Working animals shall be given proper rest periods. 
(11)  Animal bedding shall be sufficient in size and quantity, and good quality and kept clean. 
(12)  Sick or diseased animals shall be isolated from healthy animals at all times, and so segregated that the illness or disease shall not be transmitted to another animal. 
(13)  The permittee shall maintain a register of the names and addresses of persons from whom animals are received and to whom animals are sold, traded, or given. 
(14)  The permittee shall furnish to the marshal's office and to the health department the names, addresses and telephone numbers of a responsible person who has access to applicant's place of business and can be reached in an emergency at any time outside of business hours. 
(15)  Animals in cages or behind windows or in any other location shall have protection from direct sunlight and excessive heat. Shaded areas shall be provided for all animals. 
(16)  The permittee shall operate the business so as to eliminate excessive or untimely noise and offensive odors from animals. 
(17)  The permittee shall notify the owners of boarded animals when such animals refuse to eat or drink, causing them to lose flesh, or when such animals are injured, or become weak or ill. 
(Code 1987, § 6-25; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § V, 7-7-2009) 
Sec. 14-45. - Pet shops. 
The following provisions shall apply to pet shops: 
(1)  No sick or injured animal shall be maintained on the premises, sold, or offered for sale. 
(2)  Every effort shall be made to ensure that unweaned or weak animals are not sold, offered for sale, nor given away. 
(3)  Every person maintaining a pet shop shall display in a location that is visible and legible from outside such building a notice of the names, addresses and telephone numbers of responsible persons who have access to applicant's place of business and can be reached in an emergency at any time outside of business hours. 
(4)  The owner of the pet shop shall register a name for emergency contact with E 911. 
(Code 1987, § 6-26) 
Sec. 14-46. - Caged birds. 
The permittee shall display and keep birds in cages under the following conditions: 
(1)  Each bird confined in a cage shall have room to exercise freely and shall have perch space without excessive crowding. 
(2)  Sick, injured and dead birds shall be removed from cages. 
(Code 1987, § 6-27) 
Sec. 14-47. - Fish. 
The permittee shall display and keep fish in bowls or aquariums with adequate amounts of water to keep fish in a healthy condition. 
(Code 1987, § 6-28) 
Sec. 14-48. - Animal acts; pet shows; dog and cat shows and exhibitions. 
The following provisions shall apply to animal acts, pet shows, cat shows, and exhibitions: 
(1)  The permittee shall not display any animal whose condition is contrary to public decency. 
(2)  No animal shall be exhibited under conditions that may be cruel or injurious to the animal. 
(3)  No animal bearing evidence of malnutrition, ill health, or having been kept in an unsanitary condition, shall be exhibited. 
(Code 1987, § 6-29) 
Sec. 14-49. - Animal rental, stables, markets and similar pursuits. 
The following provisions shall apply to animal rental, riding academies, livery stables, boarding stables, pony rides, horse markets, mule markets, and other such pursuits: 
(1)  No animal shall be worked, used or rented when in an overheated, weakened, exhausted or crippled condition, or if diseased, ill or otherwise unfit for duty. 
(2)  Animals shall be healthy, strong, and in good flesh. 
(Code 1987, § 6-30) 
Sec. 14-50. - Keeping wild animals. 
The following provisions shall apply to the keeping of wild animals: 
(1)  The permittee shall assume full responsibility for safekeeping and for recapturing any animal that escapes from such permittee's premises. 
(2)  The permittee shall make adequate provisions and safeguards for the protection of the public. 
(3)  The permittee who applies for a permit to keep and display wild animals for educational purposes shall have available printed information concerning the animal displayed, its habits, etc., for distribution or conduct lectures concerning the animal displayed, or have adequate and explanatory signs carrying information prominently displayed near the exhibit. 
(Code 1987, § 6-31; Ord. No. 2010-01 , § VI, 7-7-2009) 
Sec. 14-51. - Circuses. 
The following provisions shall apply to circuses: 
(1)  All animals exhibited must be strong, healthy, and in good flesh. No sick, injured, or crippled animal may be exhibited or worked. 
(2)  All wild or dangerous animals must be so quartered and reasonable precautions taken to protect the public from such animals and the animals from the public. 
(3)  The permittee assumes full responsibility for safekeeping and for recapturing any animal that escapes. 
(Code 1987, § 6-32) 
Sec. 14-52. - Rodeos. 
The following provisions shall apply to rodeos: 
(1)  The applicant, when applying for a permit, shall furnish the animal control department with a detailed diagram of the area, showing location of chutes, catch chutes, and pens, and a list of all proposed events and acts and a copy of the rules and regulations which will govern the conduct of the contestants and events. All of such information will be reviewed by the zoning appeals/planning board of the county before a permit is issued. 
(2)  Any tack, equipment, device, substance or material that is or could be injurious or cause unnecessary cruelty is prohibited. 
(3)  No animal which is unfit to perform the work intended may be used. 
(4)  Chutes must be so constructed as to prevent injury to stock. The arena must be free of rocks, holes and all obstacles. 
(Code 1987, § 6-33) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS; CONSTRUCTION AND RELATED ACTIVITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Smoking in county buildings and motor vehicles, § 2-3; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 38; standards for building construction, § 38-121 et seq.; historical preservation, ch. 42; manufactured homes, ch. 46; planning, ch. 58; roads and streets, ch. 66; solid waste disposal, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. C. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building means any structure used for the habitation or assembly of humans or animals or any structure used for the manufacturing, assembly, storage or sale of goods. The term "building" shall include any addition to an existing building in such manner as to increase its capacity for the habitation or assembly of humans or animals or for the manufacture, assembly, storage or sale of goods. 
Building code means the Standard Building Code, Standard Gas Code, Standard Mechanical Code and Standard Plumbing Code, and National Electrical Code. 
Building official means an official appointed by the county manager who shall individually work through his designee, issue construction permits and inspect the workmanship of all construction within the unincorporated areas of the county. 
Construction means the erection, repair (except as excluded), location or relocation of any building. 
Owner means a property owner, lessee, renter, or an authorized contractor or authorized employee. 
Sanitary sewer system means any system used for the disposal of human, animal, manufacturing or commercial wastes and/or byproducts. 
Utilities means gas, electric, water, or sanitary sewer services provided by a public or private organization. 
Water system means any system used to supply potable water for human consumption. 
(Code 1987, § 7-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 18-2. - Dumping of construction and/or agricultural rubbish and debris. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to dump and/or bury construction and/or landscaping waste, debris, etc. on any lot upon which a residence is to be constructed in the unincorporated area of the county when such building lot is 1.5 acres or less in size. 
(Code 1987, § 13-10) 
Sec. 18-3. - County comprehensive address assignment and display guide. 
(a)  [General outline.] Building and location address numbers are to be assigned by Troup County Mapping and displayed by occupants and property owners as set forth herein. This section contains the general outline for the regulation of address number assignment and display. Procedures and specifications shall be provided in the county comprehensive address numbering and display guide to be available along with all applications and relevant fees in the county planning and zoning office. 
(b)  General address assignment regulations. The following are minimum guidelines for assignment of addresses. Specific policies and procedures shall be included in the Comprehensive Address Numbering and Display Guide available in the offices of planning and zoning. 
(1)  The county mapper shall be responsible for the approval and assignment of all addresses. 
(2)  Addresses for locations on roadways in common with neighboring jurisdictions should be coordinated to provide a logical and seamless address sequence along all roadways and to ensure no duplication of addresses in the county regardless of jurisdiction. 
(3)  The county mapper assigns new addresses that will be consistent with both the existing adjacent addresses and the county-wide numbering grid. 
(4)  Once addresses are assigned and all required documents have been submitted and approved by the county mapper, an addressing notice is prepared that is distributed to various departments and agencies (assessor's office and county communications/911) as well as many outside service providers (post office, utilities, etc.). 
(5)  Addresses shall be assigned in arabic numerals and english alphabet. 
(6)  All addresses are assigned one whole number for every ten feet; no fractional addresses are allowed (i.e., ½, etc.). Only zero lot line and single-family attached style developments, such as townhomes shall allow sequential numbering. 
(7)  Generally, addresses are assigned left to right, and with odd numbers on the left side of thoroughfares and even numbers on the right side of thoroughfares. 
(8)  Addresses are assigned only for developed property. For major subdivisions, addresses are assigned after the approval of the preliminary development plan and after an application for address assignment is submitted. All other addresses are assigned following the submission of an address assignment application with an approved building permit. 
a.  Applications shall be submitted to the county mapper in accordance with the policy guide, forms and fees created to administer this section. 
b.  Applications and addressing schemes submitted for approval to the county mapper by surveyor, engineers or other registered design professionals shall be submitted in paper formats to be legible. The county mapper shall receive all major subdivision plats electronically. 
(9)  No single parcel shall have more than one primary address. Where multiple structures exist on a single parcel of land, "root" building numbers shall be used along with suite or unit numbers where applicable. 
(c)  General address display regulations. The following are general guidelines for display of addresses. Specific policies and procedures shall be included in the Comprehensive Address Numbering and Display Guide (guide) available in planning and zoning. 
(1)  Only addresses assigned by the county mapper shall be displayed. 
(2)  Addresses shall be displayed as assigned in arabic numerals. 
(3)  Addresses should be contrasting in color to the background. Reflective lettering is encouraged for residential addresses, and may be required for certain other address types. 
(4)  Residential addresses should be displayed at the roadside adjacent to the driveway on, in order of priority: 
a.  Both sides of the structure's mailbox if adjacent to the driveway, 
b.  On a two-sided sign dedicated to the display of the address. 
(5)  If no road frontage or driveway from public right of way, then the address shall be placed within one foot of the access right-of-way or easement at the public road. 
(6)  Residential address numbers will be a minimum of four inches on all federal, state and local roads and highways and a minimum of three feet on all subdivision roads. Minimum heights shall be included in the guide. 
(7)  Nonresidential structures shall use road side and structure display as appropriate determined by development type. Nonresidential address sizes shall be determined by various factors to include location, use scale and visibility, but set forth in the guide. 
(8)  Additional standards may apply for rear-loaded, multi-family, shopping center, campus and other nontraditional or intensive development configurations. 
(9)  The chief building inspector shall enforce the address display guidelines of this section. For new construction or additions, the address display shall be approved prior to the issuance of the final certificate of occupancy (CO). 
(d)  Road naming and signing. Road names are assigned and accepted as well as road signing in accordance with the subdivision regulation of the county. Road naming and signing policies, guidelines, and procedures shall be included for informational purposes in the guide and expanded where necessary. 
Generally, the policies shall include: 
(1)  Street/road types and abbreviations should be consistent with the U.S. Post Office recognized abbreviations. 
(2)  The county mapper is solely authorized to include compass directional points (North, South, East, West, Northwest, etc.) in road names. Compass directional point words may be included in road and subdivision names when in conjunct with another word to create a single word (i.e., "Northpointe," "Southwood"). 
(3)  Road names may include english characters only. 
(4)  Initials may not be included in road names, except for memorial purposes and as specifically accepted by the county board of commissioners. 
(5)  Memorial or honoraria road names may be created by the board of commissioners. A memorial or honoraria name does not change the official road name or address of any property along that stretch of road or highway.
